bioghist.p: Dr. Ruth Myrtle Patrick (born November 26, 1907, in Topeka, Kansas) is a botanist and limnologist specializing in diatoms and freshwater ecology, who developed ways to measure the health of freshwater ecosystems and established a number of research facilities. She attended the Sunset Hill School in Kansas City, Missouri, graduating in 1925. She earned her Ph.D. at the University of Virginia in 1934. In 1937, Dr. Patrick became curator of the Academy's Leidy Microscopical Collection and in 1947, she founded the Limnology Department at The Academy of Natural Sciences. From 1973 to 1976 she was the first woman chair of The Academy of Natural Sciences’ Board of Trustees and later held the Academy’s Francis Boyer Chair of Limnology. She formed the Environmental Associates, a group of corporate executives concerned about environmental effects of industrial activities. She taught limnology and botany at the University of Pennsylvania for more than 35 years and wrote more than 200 scientific papers and a number of books on the environment, including Power So Great, Colors of Tomorrow, and the series Rivers of the United States. She has received numerous awards for her scientific achievements, including the National Medal of Science in 1996.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Dr. Ruth Patrick. Materials include: incoming and outgoing correspondence (1932-1991); memoranda, minutes, reports, and administrative files pertaining to Academy departments and committees; administrative files of organizations with which Patrick was involved, including the Environmental Associates, Environmental Assessments Council, the National Academy of Sciences, and various local, state, and national commissions; manuscripts of published and unpublished works, reprints, reference materials and data for articles and books, and correspondence with publishers, co-authors, and sponsors; lectures and addresses; reports, data, correspondence, maps, photographs, and other files related to various projects undertaken by Patrick or those under her supervision, including her book Groundwater Contamination in the United States; files of reports, articles, and studies on pollution, acid deposition, groundwater contamination, river basins, and estuaries; and miscellaneous memorabilia and photographs. The collection also includes documents related to the Ruth Patrick Fund, the Ruth Patrick Scholars program, and the celebration of Dr. Patrick's 50th anniversary at the Academy; and artifacts from the dedication of the Ruth Patrick Science Education Center, University of South Carolina, in 1991.
